Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Characterization of Cognitive Models of Conceptual Understanding in Practicing Civil Engineers and Development of Situated Curricular Materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration: This CAREER engineering education research project will advance our understanding of the differences in how engineering students and practicing engineers understand fundamental concepts of civil engineering. By mapping these differences, the project will help bridge the gap between what is taught in college and what students need to know to become effective civil engineers. Using the results of this research, educators understand be able to develop curricular materials that allow students to more rapidly enter the professional practice of engineering. A key aspect of this project is sharing the teaching tools widely among other universities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Engineering concepts are basic ideas that are taught in undergraduate and graduate courses. Example concepts are stress, deformation and strain result when a beam is loaded, or how fluid flows through a pipe. Concepts are the foundation of engineering curriculum and typically are taught as the relationship between variables. For example, the stress in a beam is related by a well-defined equation to the beam geometry, the location in the beam, and the applied load. The energy loss in a pipe is related to the fluid and pipe properties and the velocity of the fluid. In engineering practice these concepts are used, but in a design setting. For example, the choice of the size and material of a beam is related to the loads on the building, the architecture, and many other factors. The purpose of this project is to understand how practicing engineers use and understand engineering concepts. Concept inventories were implemented to practicing engineers to understand the degree to which concepts presented in this format are understood by engineers. Research also included studying how concepts were utilized in an engineering practice setting. This research is the first to examine the details in which concepts are utilized in by engineers in practice.

Three concept inventories, statics, mechanics of materials, and fluid mechanics, were implemented to practicing civil engineers. Concept inventories are multiple choice questions that are focused on engineering concepts. Correct answers align with an understanding of the concept as represented in the concept inventory question. On the other hand, incorrect answers are determined based on typical incorrect student responses. The results indicated there was no statistical difference in student and engineer scores on all three inventories. However, students performed slightly better on a majority of the questions in all three inventories while practicing engineers did better on a few questions. The results showed a difference in performance among the different types of engineers and students. For example, structural engineers performed better than students and other civil engineers on the statics concept inventory and on most individual questions. These results are important because it is often assumed that the concepts in the concept inventories are important for practicing engineers to know, and it would be assumed that engineers would do better than students. There are many feasible explanations to these results. One proposed explanation is that the form of the questions in the concept inventories does not make sense to practicing engineers in terms of the way they utilize these concepts. The form of the questions includes the drawings and the wording of the questions and answers. Based on this explanation it is very important to carefully consider the form of these inventories, and other assessments used in engineering, and the degree to which this form is applicable to engineering practice.

The research also investigated the use of engineering concepts in the design of a roundabout. A graduate student worked on a roundabout design for six months while simultaneously studying how concepts were utilized in the design process. The results demonstrated that concepts had many different forms in engineering practice. These forms included pictures, sketches, software, and written and verbal language variations. The form of concepts was broadly varied and highly dependent on the constraints of the design.

These findings may suggest that a different approach is necessary in some aspects of engineering education, specifically that concepts in engineering design have a different form, or meaning and representation, than in higher education. The form in practice is related to project constraints and many characteristics of engineering practice, like codes and software. To better prepare students for practice, engineering programs should consider the basis of learning being project constraints and the multiplicative ways in which concepts are represented and utilized within these constraints.
